ID: C1ODVNJ_00
From: James Adams <James.Adams@chalhoub.com>
To: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>; Elie Farhat <Elie.Farhat@chalhoub.com>
CC: 
BCC: 
Date: 2025-05-26 14:07
Subject: Fw: Etihad fraud incident 
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Hagop

I hope you are well

We recently had a large fraud in a phishing related incident.  Please find the the details attached.

Could you help us assess whether we can make a claim based on the current facts available?  I have copied Elie so you can connect directly with him to assess probability for the R1

Thank you


________________________________

From: Elie Farhat <Elie.Farhat@chalhoub.com>
Sent: Monday, May 26, 2025 1:19 pm
To: James Adams <James.Adams@chalhoub.com>; Mohammed El Neel <Mohammed.Elneel@chalhoub.com>
Cc: Miguel Calello <Miguel.Calello@chalhoub.com>; Salem Kaissi <Salem.Kaissi@chalhoub.com>; Souad AlKharrat <Souad.AlKharrat@chalhoub.com>; Ahmed Elsalous <Ahmed.Elsalous@chalhoub.com>
Subject: Etihad fraud incident 
 

Hi James,

Hi Mohammed,

 

Hope you are well.

 

With reference to the attached case on fraudulent transfer of two payments totalling 329,820 AED to Etihad Aviation Group, which has been identified as a suspected threat actor, need your input on defining the probability of recovery of the funds transferred through insurance.

With reference to the attached case on fraudulent transfer of two payments totalling 329,820 AED to Etihad Aviation Group, which has been identified as a suspected threat actor, need your input on defining the probability of recovery of the funds transferred through insurance.

 

We are finalizing R1 and need to factor this in.

 

Thank you

Elie

ID: C1ODVNJ_03
From: Souad AlKharrat <Souad.AlKharrat@chalhoub.com>
To: Salem Kaissi <Salem.Kaissi@chalhoub.com>; Elie Farhat <Elie.Farhat@chalhoub.com>; Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
CC: Miguel Calello <Miguel.Calello@chalhoub.com>; Nabil Chalhoub <Nabil.Chalhoub@chalhoub.com>; Ahmed Elsalous <Ahmed.Elsalous@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2025-05-27 12:32
Subject: RE: Etihad fraud incident 
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Salem, Elie,

 

I hope this message finds you well.

 

Following my discussion with @Hagop Ghazarian <mailto:Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>  regarding the Etihad fraud incident, he emphasized that there is no likelihood of a successful claim, given the absence of supplier creation and validation protocols. Consequently, we will proceed with provisioning the AED 330K as a risk in R1.

 

Please let me know if you have any alternative suggestions or directions to consider.

 

Thank you,

Hi James,

Hope all is well.

With reference to this case and based on the facts provided, the claim is unlikely to succeed.

The reasoning is that it is very likely internal procedures were not followed, as evidenced by no new supplier creation by MDM. Also, it is unlikely that a validation call was done to verify its legitimacy of the bank account details provided.

This will undoubtedly be seen as negligence or an omission, which would trigger the exclusion mentioned within the policy.

For further clarification, below is the relevant section of the policy wording related to third-party fraudulent funds transfer:

Third party computer and funds transfer fraud:

This will undoubtedly be seen as negligence or an omission, which would trigger the exclusion mentioned within the policy.

For further clarification, below is the relevant section of the policy wording related to third-party fraudulent funds transfer:

Third party computer and funds transfer fraud:

Loss discovered during the period of insurance of:
(a) property through computer fraud; or
(b) funds from the assured's transfer account at a financial institution through fraudulent transfer instructions communicated to such financial institution;
 
including but not limited to the cost of reinstating such electronic data destroyed, erased or stolen through such computer fraud or fraudulent transfer instructions as has been declared to Underwriters in the proposal as being copied and stored in a secure and separate location, but excluding any other loss consequential upon such computer fraud or fraudulent transfer instructions, provided always that Underwriters shall not be liable for any loss resulting from:
(i) loss of computer time or use;
(ii) any neglect, error or omission by or on behalf of the assured;
(iii) the voluntary giving or lending of property, or its surrender in a franchise or exchange, whether legitimate or fraudulent;
(iv) the fraudulent or dishonest act of the employee, whether acting alone or in collusion with others.

Given that internal procedures were not followed and the verification process seems to have been likely bypassed, its not likely for the claim to succeed.

Best Regards,
Hagop
